column4: try in #apache or #php or whatever whatever language you feel like doing it in :)
Web browsers are not good ftp clients
What addressa are you trying to connect to?
But that just sends you to the directory I configured in Apache.
What happens if you try to ftp into 127.0.0.1
Oho, it asks me for a username and password.  Except, the one I use on Ubuntu isn't working. ~.~
Either your router doesnt support loopback connections, or your isp is blocking port 21
Yup, its not in that list.  I don't think its started at all.
does `sudo invoke-rc.d proftpd start` give you any errors?
Hmm, says it cannot start in both standalone and inetd mode.  Check my configuration.
Check your configuration.  I believe theres a proftpd channel, either #proftp or #proftpd
I'm not sure, but proftpd users might be seperate from the system ysers.
Okay, I can check on that.
Most FTP servers will show a brief banner when the user logs in.

Gotcha, good point I didn't think about that.  I'm just trying to find a way to restrict users to their directories and such and not allow them to freely browse folders.  And I think I have to find the conf files for that ftp server.
Is there a chance that someone could use an FTP program to log in using the Open SSH server, instead of an FTP server?  Or... is there a 'default' FTP server installed with Ubuntu?
